content.description:
To the furthest right of the right boulder, find the obvious, long, left trending, diagonal crack. 

  Sit start matched at it base with your butt cramped up on a low block. Move up the crack trending left and feel free to use any good holds along the way. Top out as the crack diminishes at the lip. There are good little quartzite knobs to the right to assist with the finish.
On the left arÃªte on the left boulder find the mid-way rails to start matched on. Use the very low foot and blast up to the fun jug overhead. Mantle over the juggy ledge and continue to the top.

The dire wolf (Canis dirus "fearsome dog") is an extinct carnivorous mammal of the genus Canis, and was of heavier build the extinct gray wolf. It was most common in North America and South America 10,000 years ago... Thanks Wikipedia. 

  On the right, longer section of the two boulders, walk past the long, feint middle seam and look for the low triangle/scoop jug under the wicked steepness to sit start matched on. 

  Pop up to a good incut/flake, and then move through smaller crimps to the right. Dyno to the left facing jug/lobe, and then top out direct.

These two boulders are surely some of the most aesthetically stunning boulders in the park. Large, sweeping, steep, and full of burly lines. This was at one time one single large boulder, but the middle split and there is large opening between the two now (hence boulder(s)). The far right section of the right boulder is AVP-esque, but otherwise the texture and characteristics are more granite-like than other GHSP boulders.
